thread.title: No. 17 Portland State scores early and often in 59-42 win over No. 16 Montana State
thread.title_full: No. 17 Portland State scores early and often in 59-42 win over No. 16 Montana State | OregonLive.com

author: Scott Sepich | For The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: No. 17 Portland State scores early and often in 59-42 win over No. 16 Montana State
text:
When Portland State last played at home, the Vikings scored on their first offensive play of the game but sputtered the rest of the way in a loss to North Dakota .
Saturday against 16th-ranked Montana State, No. 17 Portland State once again scored on its first play from scrimmage.
This time, the Vikings never let up.
The Vikings scored a touchdown on their first eight offensive possessions against the visiting Bobcats, and rolled to a 59-42 win in front of 8,110 at Providence Park in a battle of ranked Football Championship Subdivision teams.
Portland State (5-1 overall, 2-1 Big Sky Conference) set a new school record for rushing yards in a single game with 465, with senior David Jones racking up 285 of those on 23 carries.
Over the last two weeks, PSU has scored 125 points and compiled 1,352 yards of offense in beating Montana State and North Texas. That stands in stark contrast to a 19-17 loss to North Dakota on Oct. 3 in which the Vikings gained 247 yards.
"I need the fans to want to come back, and we were so boring on offense against North Dakota," said PSU head coach Bruce Barnum , who was given a five-year contract earlier this week. "Something had to be done. We have the tools, we just had to put it together."
The Vikings were far from boring Saturday, averaging 8.6 yards per play in gaining 682 yards of total offense. They needed it to keep pace with the Bobcats, who gained 440 yards overall but only 181 in the second half.
Portland State went 11 for 14 on third down, and didn't punt until there were 23 seconds left in the game. Quarterback Alex Kuresa 's lost fumble on the Vikings' ninth possession was their first empty trip, but the defense responded by stopping Montana State (3-3, 2-2) on fourth down at the PSU 11-yard line.
"We have several different guys making plays, and we're doing it on big downs," said Kuresa, who completed 10 of 14 passes for 217 yards and a touchdown. "Any time you get backed up and convert on third down, it's frustrating for a defense.
"Maybe the first few weeks we weren't making those plays, but it's contagious now."
After MSU quarterback Dakota Prukop scored on a 61-yard run 1:21 into the game, Jones went 79 yards on PSU's first play to even the score. Prukop scored again on the Bobcats' next possession, but Nate Tago, Paris Penn and Thomas Carter scored consecutive touchdowns to give the Vikings a 28-14 lead.
"We left some points on the field against North Dakota, so that was a rude awakening," said Jones, whose 285-yard performance ranks fifth in a single game in school history. "We realize we needed to score some points to help our defense out."
Kuresa's three-yard touchdown run after another Prukop score made it 35-21 Vikings at halftime. Jones ran for touchdowns of 26 and 56 yards in the first four minutes of the third quarter, sandwiched around a 100-yard kickoff return touchdown by MSU's Logan Jones.
Penn's second touchdown helped the Vikings maintain a 56-42 lead through three, then PSU played a ball-control game in the fourth quarter. A 12-play, 77-yard drive resulting in a field goal ate up 6:42 on the clock and closed out the scoring.
"I liked the attitude, and I like how we are right now," Barnum said. "The kids are where we want them. We play sandlot football, and we have fun playing the game."
With the win, Barnum had to make good on an offer to buy fans a beer after the game at a bar near Providence Park. He feigned despair when talking about paying the tab, commenting that "my wife will have to have a couple or I'll be in trouble when I get home."
Barnum reiterated, though, that he's trying to do whatever he can to help rebuild the PSU fanbase.
"I'd love to have people come out and watch these games," he said. "They play the game the way it's supposed to be played. It's a clean game and they respect it, win or lose."
Next week, the Vikings travel south to face Cal Poly, a program led by former PSU head coach Tim Walsh. The Mustangs are 2-4, but lost to conference power Eastern Washington by one point in their last game.
"Tim's the guy I picked to win the conference," Barnum said of his preseason coaches' poll vote. "No week is easy. We earned another six days of glory, but we'll get ready for next week."
-- Scott Sepich for The Oregonian/OregonLive
